summary: This document is a compilation of news articles from July 9, 2019, focusing primarily on the arrest and indictment of Jeffrey Epstein on federal sex trafficking charges in the Southern District of New York. It details the allegations, the controversial 2008 plea deal in Florida overseen by Alexander Acosta, Epstein's connections to powerful figures, and the political and legal fallout. It also includes other unrelated news summaries.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy financier indicted on federal sex trafficking charges for allegedly operating a network exploiting dozens of minor girls from 2002-2005 from his homes in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

persons.name: Alexander Acosta
persons.role: U.S. Secretary of Labor, former U.S. Attorney for Southern District of Florida
persons.context: As U.S. Attorney in 2008, he oversaw the controversial non-prosecution plea deal with Epstein that resulted in minimal jail time and is now under review by the DOJ.

persons.name: Geoffrey Berman
persons.role: U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Prosecuting the 2019 case against Epstein, argued for him to be held without bail, and credited investigative journalism for assisting the case.

persons.name: Bill Barr
persons.context: Announced he would not recuse himself from the new Epstein prosecution but would recuse from the internal DOJ review of the 2008 plea deal due to his former law firm's prior representation of Epstein.

persons.name: Bill Clinton
persons.context: Described as a friend of Epstein; his photograph was displayed in Epstein's mansion; he took trips on Epstein's plane but claims to have severed ties over a decade ago.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Described as a former friend of Epstein; quoted in 2002 praising him; photographed with him at Mar-a-Lago.

persons.name: Leslie Wexner
persons.role: Founder and chairman of L Brands
persons.context: Epstein's mentor and primary financial client; originally purchased Epstein's Manhattan mansion and later transferred ownership to him.

persons.name: Julie K. Brown
persons.role: Investigative reporter for The Miami Herald
persons.context: Her 2018 investigative series "Perversion of Justice" exposed the details of Epstein's 2008 plea deal and gave victims a voice, credited with reviving the case.

persons.name: Vicky Ward
persons.context: Wrote a 2003 Vanity Fair profile on Epstein; claims the editor cut first-person accounts of alleged abuse from two sisters; discussed her reporting and Epstein's threats.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's girlfriend who helped recruit and reassure victims; daughter of Robert Maxwell.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Mentioned as one of the boldfaced names Epstein socialized with; the case is likely to cause him embarrassment.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Mentioned as having written a letter to Pulitzer judges criticizing Julie Brown's reporting as 'fake news'.

persons.name: R. Couri Hay
persons.context: Invited to Epstein's home to view a prison-themed mural; Epstein sought his help for damage control but he declined.

persons.name: James Cayne
persons.context: Praised Epstein's skills at Bear Stearns; Epstein remained close to him and Alan Greenberg.

persons.name: Alan Greenberg
persons.context: Epstein taught his son at Dalton; helped Epstein get a job at Bear Stearns; remained a client.

persons.name: Steve Hoffenberg
persons.context: Described as having taught Epstein financial tricks; went to jail for a Ponzi scheme; claims Epstein has his money.

persons.name: Mimi Rocah
persons.context: Authored an opinion piece analyzing the new Epstein prosecution, its legal hurdles, and potential for cooperation.

persons.name: Michael Gyure
persons.role: Former executive director of the Friars Club
persons.context: Subject of an unrelated news item; sentenced for filing false tax returns in a case that divided club members.

persons.name: Fred Warmbier
persons.context: Subject of an unrelated news item; filed a lawsuit to seize a North Korean ship as compensation for his son's death.

persons.name: Cindy Warmbier
persons.context: Subject of an unrelated news item; filed a lawsuit with her husband seeking compensation from North Korea.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, approved the 2008 non-prosecution plea deal for Epstein, sparing him federal charges.
Wexner was Epstein's primary financial client and mentor; Epstein acquired his Manhattan mansion from him.
Maxwell was Epstein's girlfriend and is accused of helping recruit and schedule underage girls for him.
Social friends; Clinton flew on Epstein's plane multiple times and visited his home; Epstein displayed his photo.
Social friends prior to the allegations; Trump praised him in a 2002 interview and was photographed with him.
Barr's former law firm, Kirkland & Ellis, represented Epstein in 2008, leading to Barr's recusal from the review of the old case but not the new prosecution.
Brown's investigative reporting for the Miami Herald extensively covered Epstein's crimes and the plea deal, reviving public and legal interest.
Ward profiled Epstein in 2003; he threatened her during her reporting, and her editor cut allegations of abuse from her story.
Barr, as Attorney General, is overseeing the DOJ but recused himself from the internal review of Acosta's handling of the 2008 Epstein case.

events.title: Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was arrested by federal agents at Teterboro Airport in New Jersey upon returning from Paris.

events.title: Indictment Unsealed / Court Appearance
events.description: A 14-page federal indictment was unsealed in the Southern District of New York charging Epstein with sex trafficking and conspiracy. Epstein pleaded not guilty at his arraignment.

events.title: Search of Epstein's Manhattan Mansion
events.description: FBI agents executed a search warrant at Epstein's Upper East Side townhouse, prying open the door. They recovered hundreds or thousands of sexually suggestive photographs, some appearing to be of underage girls.

events.title: Florida Plea Deal
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty to state charges of soliciting prostitution from a minor in a deal orchestrated by then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta. He served 13 months in a county jail with work release, avoided federal charges, and co-conspirators were granted immunity.

events.title: Federal Judge Rules Victims' Rights Violated
events.description: A federal judge ruled that the 2008 plea deal violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by not notifying Epstein's victims.

events.title: Barr Announces Recusal Decision
events.description: Attorney General William Barr announced he would not recuse himself from the new SDNY prosecution of Epstein but would recuse from the DOJ review of the 2008 plea deal.

events.title: Alleged Sex Trafficking Operation
events.description: Epstein allegedly operated a sex trafficking ring, exploiting dozens of minor girls at his homes in Manhattan and Palm Beach, paying them and having them recruit others.

locations: Little St. James Island, U.S. Virgin Islands
Southern District of New York (SDNY) court
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was indicted on federal sex trafficking charges in SDNY for allegedly exploiting dozens of minor girls from 2002-2005, facing up to 45 years in prison.

The 2008 plea deal in Florida, overseen by then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta, allowed Epstein to serve only 13 months in county jail, avoid federal charges, and granted immunity to co-conspirators, a deal a judge later ruled violated victims' rights.
A search of Epstein's Manhattan mansion in July 2019 yielded 'hundreds—and perhaps thousands—of sexually suggestive photographs' of females, some appearing to be underage.
Attorney General William Barr recused himself from the DOJ review of the 2008 plea deal due to his former law firm's prior representation of Epstein but will oversee the new SDNY prosecution.
Investigative journalism, particularly Julie K. Brown's 2018 Miami Herald series 'Perversion of Justice,' is credited by prosecutors with reviving the case and giving victims a voice.
